title: ASIC raided top lawyer's home in Hutson case
text:
Ms Greaves told the court she had pleaded guilty because “I wanted to get it dealt with and get on with my life”.

But she also faced a grilling on “inconsistent”, “very different” and “detailed” accounts with what she told ASIC in 2016, and subsequent statements to the regulatory watchdog that are being used in charges against Ms Hutson.

The testimony came during a committal hearing into charges levelled against Ms Hutson, herself a top corporate lawyer and company director of entities ranging from accommodation to childcare.

Ms Hutson, 51, is vigorously defending charges that include dishonestly using her position as a director, giving false information to the Australian Securities Exchange about a takeover and attempting to pervert the course of justice.

The charges centre on when Ms Hutson was chairwoman of childcare giant G8 Education in 2015. The then 460-centre outfit had launched a takeover of rival Affinity Education. The hearing is testing evidence about how another businessman, Nigel Elias, acquired $8.5 million shares in Affinity.

The court has heard allegations that Ms Hutson arranged for G8’s finances to be used to fund the purchases. Mr Elias has not been charged.

Ms Greaves was general counsel for Wellington Capital, Ms Hutson’s merchant bank.

ASIC had been investigating the matter and conducted Section 19 examinations in June 2016. Two months later, they raided Ms Greaves’s Brisbane home and found items, the court heard.

Advertisement

The raid came as Ms Greaves was leaving to go to work. An ASIC officer left her a card and asked her to come in for a voluntary interview.

Neil Clelland, representing Ms Hutson, asked if Ms Greaves had been fearful of being charged with criminal offences. “I guess I was. My house had just been raided,” she said.

Ms Greaves later gave statements to ASIC, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to a two-year good behaviour bond, the court heard.

Ms Greaves maintained on Tuesday she had tried to be truthful with ASIC in the initial interrogation.

That included Ms Greaves initially indicating to ASIC officers that the first she had known about Mr Elias acquiring Affinity Education shares was when she read newspaper reports.

But her subsequent statements to ASIC detailed an alleged conversation she had with Ms Hutson about Mr Elias’s ability to purchase shares, and another discussion in which Ms Hutson allegedly told her to relay that Mr Elias should not put certain details in an email.

Mr Clelland went through “numerous” examples of differences in Ms Greaves 2016 answers and in subsequent statements.

”You say to her Honour, on your oath, that this nonetheless, [is] simply a case of you having been afflicted by memory loss at the time of your Section 19 examination [in 2016], being unable to remember certain things, and then by the time March [2017] rolls around, you have acquired – not just a recollection of some matters – but a very detailed recollection of matters that is quite inconsistent with the answers you gave in your section 19 examination,” he said.

Ms Greaves agreed.
description: Former general counsel tells she believed she had been rattled by the raid and eventually sought indemnity from any prosecution.
